executive_summary: Rising incomes and shifting consumer preferences have translated into revenue growth for health stores in recent years. More than ever, consumers value the importance of active and healthy lifestyles. At the same time, higher incomes allow people to integrate vitamins, supplements and other health products into their daily lives. While this has benefited health stores, mounting competition from alternative retailers is offsetting the growing popularity of health and wellness products. A booming health and wellness market has incentivized a range of alternative retailers, from popular beauty stores (Sephora, Ulta) to pharmacies and big-box retailers (Target, Walmart), to expand offerings of health products. Still, industry revenue is rising at a CAGR of 4.9%, reaching an estimated $47.4 billion in 2024, when revenue will jump an expected 1.0%.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Pandemic Concerns Strengthen Vitamin and Supplement Sales
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Pandemic-related economic disruptions had the opposite effect on vitamin and supplement sales, as concerned consumers sought health products to boost their and their family's immunities. According to the National Health Institute, sales of multivitamins spiked in March 2020, with over a 50.0% jump.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Pandemic Concerns Strengthen Vitamin and Supplement Sales
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: But the pandemic also transformed how people shop. Online retailers like Amazon took sales from health stores even as temporary closures lifted. While the pandemic-induced sales boom has subsided, consumers continue to make purchases supporting immunity but gravitate more toward lifestyle products.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Recession concerns and a higher living cost in 2023 will likely dent spending on discretionary health products.
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Rising spending on health products in recent years will likely slow in 2024 as higher living costs limit discretionary spending. Still, overarching demand from the growing over-65 population and millennials will support spending on health products moving forward. But, more consumers are anticipated to purchase vitamins and supplements at retailers they already visit, like Target or Sephora, as these stores introduce more health and wellness items. In all, industry-wide revenue is forecast to expand at a CAGR of 1.8% over the five years through 2029 to total $51.9 billion.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: An Uptick in Health-Conscious Consumers Influences Trends
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Consumers in the US are more health-conscious than ever before. Millennials are a driving force behind higher spending on health and wellness products. This age group values healthy lifestyles and is more willing to spend on high-margin items. An aging population is also responsible for rising sales of vitamins and supplements that support healthy aging. Social media and influencers are introducing more people to health and wellness fads, leading to several sales spikes of specific supplements and vitamins in recent years.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Rising Competition Offsets the Rising Popularity of Health and Wellness
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Growing sales of health and wellness haven't gone unnoticed by other retailers. A broad range of alternative retailers, from popular beauty stores (Sephora, Ulta) to pharmacies and big-box retailers (Target, Walmart), have expanded their offerings of health products. These retailers pull sales away from health stores by offering consumers cost-savings or convenience. Direct-to-consumer (DTC) companies are also disrupting health stores. DTCs are taking consumers (mainly high-earning millennials) through digital advertising, tongue-in-cheek messaging and trendy graphics.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: CONSUMER TRENDS WILL INFLUENCE HEALTH SPENDING
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Wellness will remain a priority for consumers post-COVID. Rising incomes will allow health-conscious consumers to expand health product spending. A shift in how consumers value health and wellness products could also make health stores more resilient to economic fluctuations. An aging population will continue spending on supplements to support healthy aging. Yet, mounting healthcare costs could constrain spending by this demographic. Millennials value health and wellness more than other generations did. As millennials earning power grows, their spending on health products will accelerate. The popularity of TikTok and other social media apps will continue altering the health and wellness market. Social media influencers and viral trends will encourage younger consumers to purchase health products.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: A BOOMING HEALTH AND WELLNESS MARKET WILL INTRODUCE NEW COMPETITORS
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: An already competitive health and wellness space won't see competition subside. A growing shift in consumer preferences for healthy lifestyles will incentivize alternative retailers like grocery stores and big-box stores like Target to expand product offerings. Small, owner-operated health stores could struggle to compete with these retailers as consumers will have fewer reasons to visit stores. New, niche health retailers will enter the space, focusing on untapped markets.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: HEALTH STORES WILL NEED TO ADAPT TO COMPETE
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Staying on top of changing consumer preferences will be more critical than ever for health stores to remain competitive in a crowded market. Integrating tech tools and expanding their digital footprint will be necessary as consumers increasingly expect contactless payments or autoship options. Social media trends can create sudden demand shocks for a specific product. Health stores will have to foresee and navigate these sales spikes.

industry_definition: Health stores include retailers that primarily sell health and personal care products, including nutritional supplement stores, convalescent and prosthetic supply stores and specialized medical supply stores.
key_trends: Health stores navigate a new normal after the pandemic-induced sales frenzy. Pandemic concerns and social media trends spiked sales of vitamins between 2020 and 2021, but steadying demand and higher living costs will slow purchases through 2024.

A booming health and wellness space has incentivized more retailers to give shelf space to supplements. Health stores navigate a more competitive market as major retailers like Target and Sephora take advantage of this growing category.
Health stores don't receive any direct public or private assistance. Retailers are supported by networks of industry associations instead.
Rising incomes support spending on vitamins and supplements. As per capita income grows, consumers can afford to integrate health products into their everyday lives.
Health trends influence what consumers buy. Pandemic concerns created a sales spike in vitamins, while social media trends led more consumers to purchase supplements for sleep and mindfulness.
Millennials are a growing market for health stores. High-earning millennials' focus on wellness encourages them to integrate premium health products into daily life.
The distribution of health stores in the US follows population trends. Large populations in the Southeast and West give health stores access to the most potential customers.
Just a handful of health retailers have a hold on the market. Leading retailers like GNC and The Vitamin Shoppe are synonymous with health and wellness products.

Competition from substitutes is disrupting traditional health stores. More retailers like big-box stores, pharmacies and direct-to-consumer brands are offering health and wellness products, giving consumers more options to choose from.
Leading health store retailer GNC has struggled in recent years. GNC's balance sheet continues to struggle following the company's bankruptcy filing in 2020 and closure of over 1,200 locations.
Health stores are paying more for inventory from upstream suppliers. Supply chain disruptions, elevated transportation costs and higher input prices have increased purchasing costs.
Mounting competition is constraining profit growth. Consumers have more choices than ever regarding where to buy health products, pressuring health stores.

market_segmentation.segment: Consumers Aged 45 to 64 are the Top Spenders at Health Stores
market_segmentation.segment_description: Consumers between 45 to 64 are the largest market for health stores. Consumers in this age group usually have higher disposable incomes to spend on health and wellness products for themselves and their families. Aging adults purchase supplements as preventative measures and to support the mind and body in healthy aging.

market_segmentation.segment: Consumers Aged 25 to 44 Spend Robustly on Health Products, but Health Stores Don't Always Benefit
market_segmentation.segment_description: Consumers aged 25 to 44 are a growing market for health stores. Millennials are a driving force behind higher spending on health and wellness products. This age group values healthy lifestyles more than earlier generations did. Consumers in this age group are more willing to spend on high-margin items and introduce them into their everyday lives. Competition from direct-to-consumer (DTC) brands and alternative retailers (Sephora, CVS, Target) targets this age group. These consumers are likelier to try new health fads or niche DTC companies.

market_segmentation.segment: Consumers Aged 65 and Older Purchase Supplements and Vitamins to Support Active Lifestyles
market_segmentation.segment_description: Consumers aged 65 and older are the third-largest market for health stores. An aging population is responsible for rising sales of vitamins and supplements. But these consumers are less likely to experiment with new premium offerings or follow health fads. A focus on active and healthy lifestyles later in life is supporting supplement sales that promote healthy minds and joint health.

market_segmentation.segment: Consumers 25 and Under are Entering the Health and Wellness Space
market_segmentation.segment_description: Consumers aged 25 and under are the smallest market for health stores. Young consumers have limited income to spend on wellness products, while their age makes them less susceptible to common ailments or concerns that older consumers are. Social media and influencers are introducing a younger audience to health and wellness fads, creating several sales spikes of specific supplements.

products_and_services.product_description: Health supplements include vitamins and minerals (multivitamins, amino acids, antioxidants). Supplements often target a specific concern (energy, joint health) and age or gender demographic.
Cosmetic and beauty products include personal care products (shampoo, toothpaste), skincare items (eye cream, cleansers) and beauty supplements (collagen, biotin).
Sports nutrition products include performance supplements and protein powders.
Nutritional products include gut health and digestion supplements (probiotics), weight loss aids (meal replacements, dietary supports) and food and drinks.

tier_1_suppliers: Drug, Cosmetic & Toiletry Wholesaling in the US
Medical Supplies Wholesaling in the US
Laboratory Supply Wholesaling in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Generic Pharmaceutical Manufacturing in the US
Vitamin & Supplement Manufacturing in the US
Intellectual Property Licensing in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Consumers are Increasingly Taking Charge of Their Health Through Supplements
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Consumers, more than ever, are taking their and their family's health into their own hands by researching what supplements are best to address their concerns. Two demographics behind rising spending on supplements are millennials and the over-65 cohort. High-earning millennials are major spenders on premium supplements, while older people look for products to support healthy aging. Social media trends are increasingly influencing sales of health supplements. Trend-driven demand drove sales of liquid chlorophyll in 2021, leading many stores to sell out entirely. Concerned consumers sought out supplements that boosted immunity during the pandemic.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Cosmetic and Beauty Products are a Fast-Growing Category
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Consumers are increasingly taking a holistic approach to beauty, adjusting purchases to include natural and organic skincare and body products. Health stores sell all-natural beauty products not commonly found at pharmacies or big-box retailers like Target.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: A MORE DIVERSE GROUP OF CONSUMERS ARE PURCHASING SPORTS NUTRITION PRODUCTS
demand_determinants.determinant_description: A rising focus on healthy and active lifestyles leads a broader range of consumers to purchase performance supplements, including females and older adults. Other consumers are increasing their purchases of protein products to meet dietary and lifestyle goals.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: CONSUMER TRENDS INFLUENCE NUTRITIONAL AID SALES
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Heightened consumer interest in gut health is increasing purchases of probiotics. According to Food Dive, a food industry news source, the pandemic led more consumers to rethink their food purchases and wellness, pushing up sales of probiotics. Some states are introducing legislation restricting sales of over-the-counter diet pills and weight loss supplements to people under 18. New York is the latest state to introduce legislation.

business_locations.location_description: More than one-quarter of the nation's population resides in the Southeast region. Since the distribution of health stores follows population trends, this region has the most stores in the US.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) enforces federal consumer protection laws overseeing practices related to product pricing, marketing, consumer privacy, antitrust and payment processing.
The Occupational Health and Safety Act (OSHA) requires employers to display workers' rights poster and comply with safety regulations.
The US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) sets guidelines and regulations for health stores selling perishable foods on proper handling and foodborne illness prevention.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Health stores are labor-intensive. Acquiring and retaining staff is essential for stores to run day-to-day operations.

basis_points.basis_description: Just a handful of health retailers like GNC and The Vitamin Shoppe have a hold on the market and are synonymous with health and wellness products.
Independent retailers endure an increasingly competitive market as more alternative retailers introduce health and wellness products, giving consumers less reason to visit a health store.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Fragmented industry with small local retailers
concentration_points.concentration_description: Health stores are highly fragmented – most stores are small, owner-operated retailers serving a well-defined local area.
Small retailers catering to customers' specific health and wellness needs are a preferred method of shopping for vitamins, supplements and nutritional items.
Alternative retail channels for health items like online retailers, pharmacies and grocery stores also keep the industry fragmented.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Acquiring and maintaining inventory is health stores' most considerable expense, with purchase costs eating over half of revenue annually on average.
What health stores are paying employees has stayed relatively the same in recent years despite the impact of the pandemic, labor shortages, inflation and external employment trends.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Health stores are labor-intensive. Acquiring and retaining staff is essential for stores to run day-to-day operations.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Low rate of new patent technologies
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The rate of new patent technologies entering the industry is low, which limits the potential for innovations.
Major market segments for industry operators are relatively diversified.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Rising health consciousness and shifting consumer preferences toward healthy lifestyles influence consumers' spending on food, vitamins and supplements.
The FDA doesn't regulate many products sold at health stores. Changes in the FDA's regulation over dietary supplements and vitamins can create some volatility.
Spending at health stores is sensitive to changes in economic conditions like unemployment and consumer confidence.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in one corner of the market or do you retail a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: Health store products vary significantly, ranging from general vitamins to specific proteins and supplements for athletes. There is potential to appeal to a wide range of customers when companies diversify their product offerings.

FAQs.question: Health stores are facing various forms of disruption, including e-commerce and big-box retailers, such as Target and Walmart. Do you differentiate through innovation? If not, how do you differentiate from competitors?
FAQs.answer: Many health stores differentiate themselves from competitors through customer service and other perks, like complimentary evaluations and helping customers pick exactly what they need based on the outcome they want.

FAQs.question: Customer service is a very important aspect, especially in industries like Health Stores where many customers are relying on the advice of store employees. What steps do you take to retain talented employees with specialized knowledge?
FAQs.answer: Health stores entice employees by offering a competitive salary and benefits.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored acquisition opportunities in order to expand reach to a broader customer base and reduce overhead expenses?
FAQs.answer: By acquiring other companies, businesses can expand their offerings and appeal to a larger consumer base. Recently, Vitamin Shoppe was acquired by a private company based in China. However, the majority of small specialty retailers are single-store companies that serve a specific geographic area. As a result, merger and acquisition activity is less common in this industry compared to other retail industries.

FAQs.question: Many retailers have been able to implement technology, like automated customer service responses, to reduce labor. Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Unlike other retail industries, health stores require employees knowledgeable in fitness and nutrition to help customers find the right products, limiting the ability to reduce wage costs through automation.

FAQs.question: What does your company do to remain compliant with new consumer regulations, such as the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (FDCA)?
FAQs.answer: Health stores are subject to regulations by a number of federal agencies, including the Food and Drug Administration (FDA), the Federal Trade Commission (FTC), the Consumer Product Safety Commission and the US Postal Service (USPS). Not all supplements are FDA-approved, meaning that the majority of products are subject to strict packaging rules that outline the risk of taking non-FDA-approved substances.

FAQs.question: How do you handle compliance with health claims and advertising regulations in your industry?
FAQs.answer: Regulatory compliance around health claims and advertising is critical to maintaining positive customer perception and avoiding legal issues.

FAQs.question: How does fluctuation in supplier prices impact your pricing strategies and profit?
FAQs.answer: Fluctuations in supplier prices can significantly impact pricing strategies and profitability. Maintaining close relations with upstream wholesalers can help health stores offer the lowest prices possible.

FAQs.question: Many retailers have increasingly implemented financing options through third-party applications, such as Afterpay, Quadpay and Klarna. Do you have any challenges with customers paying on time?
FAQs.answer: The majority of health store products are small and discretionary, and so financing is typically not provided to customers. This means health stores don't usually run into problems with customers paying on time. However, as more retailers implement payment systems, there is a greater risk of customers not paying on time.

FAQs.question: Do you manufacture any branded products? How do you promote your products and services? How can you improve this process?
FAQs.answer: A growing number of retailers are stocking private-label products. Consumers tend to purchase health products from brands that they know and trust. Certain national brands are highly sought after, so health retailers should ensure adequate stock of these.

FAQs.question: How do you hire workers? What is the training process for new hires like? How much prior experience is necessary for workers at your company?
FAQs.answer: Knowledgeable and experienced staff can better provide advice on what supplements or apparatuses would best suit the customer's requirements. This is particularly important when competing with mass retailers.

FAQs.question: How do you respond to variability in consumer demand? Are you able to quickly and easily alter the services offered?
FAQs.answer: Health stores must evaluate their offerings to meet consumer demands and differentiate themselves from competitors. It is particularly important when competing with mass retailers to ensure that a company's offerings don't overlap with the products of these competitors. Health retailers have had to increasingly stock natural products in stores as more consumers opt for cleaner ingredients.

FAQs.question: Do you track trends in the percentage of services conducted online? How has the move to online purchases of jewelry benefited your business?
FAQs.answer: A rise in the percentage of services conducted online translates to less demand for traditional brick-and-mortar stores.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor trends in per capita disposable income? How does an increase in disposable income affect demand?
FAQs.answer: Discretionary purchases at health stores climb as disposable income rises and heightened consumer confidence leads to more spending on healthy living.

FAQs.question: How do changes in the healthy eating index affect your company? Do you monitor changes in the healthy eating index?
FAQs.answer: A rise in the healthy eating index indicates healthier lifestyles among consumers. The popularity of these attitudes drives demand for health store products. At the same time, decline in the healthy eating index can actually benefit industry performance as consumers seek to remedy health issues.
